conversation.content: [confused] Maya? That can't be— [gasps] Jesus Christ, it is you. What the hell are you doing with these people? We used to play soccer together in your grandmother's yard.
[bitter] These people? [loudly] These people are the only family I have left after your drones killed everyone else in the market bombing last spring. [very quietly] Including my grandmother.
[shaky voice] That wasn't me, Maya. I fly surveillance missions, reconnaissance only. [defensively] I track movements, I don't drop bombs, I would never—
[furious] You think that makes you innocent? [shouting] Your intel tells them where to strike! Every coordinate you send back is a death sentence for someone's family!

[quietly] You think I don't know that? [pause] I see their faces through the cameras sometimes, the people going about their lives, and I have to tag them as targets or non-targets like they're just data points.
[sarcastically] Must be so hard for you.
You joined them, Maya. The rebels. [sighs] After everything we promised each other about staying out of this war, you picked up a rifle and became exactly what we swore we'd never be.
[firmly] I didn't have a choice!

[empathetically] There's always a choice. [very quietly] I chose the government because they threatened my sister's scholarship, said they'd revoke her visa if I didn't enlist. [trailing off] What was your reason?
[long pause] They killed my parents.
[whispering] Oh God, Maya, I didn't know.

[warmly] Remember when we were kids and thought we'd open that restaurant together? [sad] You'd handle the business side and I'd cook all my grandmother's recipes, serve real food to people, not military rations.
[melancholic] I still have that notebook where we drew the floor plans. [chuckles] You insisted on having a wood-fire oven even though neither of us knew how to build one.

[hesitantly] Listen, my commander will be here in twenty minutes to interrogate you. [very quietly] They're going to want drone codes, base locations, everything you know about the surveillance network.
And when I don't give them what they want? Because I won't, Maya. [firmly] I can't betray my unit any more than you could betray yours.

[anxious] They have ways of making people talk that I don't want to see happen to you. [whispering loudly] There's a guard shift change in fifteen minutes, the south fence has a gap near the generator.
[confused] Why are you telling me this? [pause] If they find out you helped me escape, they'll execute you for treason.

[very sincerely] Because somewhere under all this uniform and anger, you're still that kid who shared their lunch with me every day for a year when my family couldn't afford food. [sighs] That has to count for something.
If I run, we'll be enemies next time we meet. Real enemies. [shaky voice] I might have to mark you as a target on my screen, just another heat signature to track.

[crying while speaking] Then we'll be enemies. [firmly] But right now, for the next ten minutes, you're just Danny and I'm just Maya, and I'm giving my friend a chance to live. [whispering] Please take it.

scenario: A military drone operator crashes in rebel territory and is captured by a rebel fighter who turns out to be their childhood friend from before the war.
